title: Song of Solomon Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Song of Solomon chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Song of Solomon Chapter 4.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 4:1, what are described as 'within thy locks'?
questions.correctAnswer: Doves' eyes
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states, 'thou hast doves' eyes within thy locks.'

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:2, thy teeth are compared to what?
questions.correctAnswer: A flock of sheep
questions.explanation: Verse 2 says, 'Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep that are even shorn.'

questions.question: What is the color of the lips described in Song of Solomon 4:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Scarlet
questions.explanation: Verse 3 describes the lips as 'like a thread of scarlet.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 4:4, what is likened to the neck?
questions.correctAnswer: The tower of David
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states, 'Thy neck is like the tower of David builded for an armoury.'

questions.question: Song of Solomon 4:5 compares the two breasts to what animals?
questions.correctAnswer: Two young roes
questions.explanation: Verse 5 compares the breasts to 'two young roes that are twins.'

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:6, to what places does the speaker say he will go until the day breaks?
options: The mountain of myrrh and the hill of frankincense
The valley of kings and the sea of glass
The city of David and the mount of olives
The garden of Eden and the river of life
questions.correctAnswer: The mountain of myrrh and the hill of frankincense
questions.explanation: Verse 6 says, 'I will get me to the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.'

questions.question: What does Song of Solomon 4:7 say about the beloved?
options: There is no spot in thee
Thou art radiant like the sun
Thy voice is like a melody
questions.correctAnswer: There is no spot in thee
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states, 'Thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee.'

questions.question: From where does the speaker invite his spouse to come in Song of Solomon 4:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Lebanon
questions.explanation: Verse 8 invites, 'Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 4:9, what has the beloved ravished?
questions.correctAnswer: My heart
questions.explanation: Verse 9 says, 'Thou hast ravished my heart.'

questions.question: What is said to be better than wine in Song of Solomon 4:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy love
questions.explanation: Verse 10 says, 'How much better is thy love than wine!'

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 4:11 describes the spouse's lips as dropping honeycomb.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states, 'Thy lips, O my spouse, drop as the honeycomb.'

questions.question: True or False: In Song of Solomon 4:12, the garden is described as open and accessible.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 12 describes the garden as 'inclosed,' 'a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.'

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 4:15 speaks of 'a well of living waters' and streams from Lebanon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 15 says, 'A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Song of Solomon 4:13: 'Thy plants are an orchard of _______, with pleasant fruits.'
questions.correctAnswer: pomegranates
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states, 'Thy plants are an orchard of pomegranates, with pleasant fruits.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Song of Solomon 4:16: 'Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my _______, that the spices thereof may flow out.'
questions.correctAnswer: garden
questions.explanation: Verse 16 says, 'blow upon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out.'

medium.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Song of Solomon Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with contentment in their marriage. Based on Song of Solomon 4, what biblical truth about love and appreciation would you share?
options: Love involves seeing your spouse as completely fair and without spot
Love requires constant correction and criticism
Marriage is mainly a duty without joy
Physical appearance is the only important factor in love
questions.correctAnswer: Love involves seeing your spouse as completely fair and without spot
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:7 says, 'Thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee,' emphasizing the appreciation and admiration in love. Verses 4:1 and 4:3 also show affectionate description, encouraging believers to cherish and honor their spouses.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 4 teach us about perseverance through trials in relationships?
options: By encouraging the couple to wait until the day breaks and shadows flee
By advising immediate separation during conflict
By prioritizing personal desires over unity
By ignoring conflicts and pretending they don't exist
questions.correctAnswer: By encouraging the couple to wait until the day breaks and shadows flee
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:6 says, 'Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mountain of myrrh.' This metaphor encourages patience and hope through difficult times, symbolizing perseverance in love and relationships.

questions.question: A believer wants to cultivate a prayerful and intimate relationship with God. How does Song of Solomon 4:16 illustrate this type of spiritual longing?
options: By awakening the winds to blow upon the garden, symbolizing prayerful invitation
By commanding silence and solitude only
By focusing solely on ritual without heart engagement
By avoiding any expression of desire or longing
questions.correctAnswer: By awakening the winds to blow upon the garden, symbolizing prayerful invitation
questions.explanation: Verse 4:16 says, 'Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my garden,' representing fervent prayer and invitation to God’s presence, encouraging believers to actively seek intimacy with God.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 4 teach about humility and gratitude in marriage?
options: By expressing admiration for the beloved’s qualities and giving thanks
By boasting about oneself and demanding admiration
By ignoring the spouse’s good qualities
By comparing the spouse unfavorably to others
questions.correctAnswer: By expressing admiration for the beloved’s qualities and giving thanks
questions.explanation: Verses 4:9-10 express deep admiration and gratitude: 'Thou hast ravished my heart... How fair is thy love! how much better is thy love than wine!' This teaches humility and gratitude towards one’s spouse.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation and asks how to remain faithful. What principle about guarding one’s heart can be drawn from Song of Solomon 4:12?
options: Keep your heart like a sealed fountain, protected and pure
Give in quickly to temptation without resistance
Ignore spiritual discipline and rely on feelings
Open your heart to every influence without discretion
questions.correctAnswer: Keep your heart like a sealed fountain, protected and pure
questions.explanation: Verse 4:12 says, 'A garden inclosed... a fountain sealed,' symbolizing purity and guardedness, teaching believers to protect their hearts from impurity and temptation.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 4:4 illustrate the virtue of integrity and strength in personal character?
options: By comparing the neck to the tower of David, a strong armory with mighty shields
By describing weakness and vulnerability as desirable
By encouraging deceit to protect oneself
By ignoring the need for moral strength
questions.correctAnswer: By comparing the neck to the tower of David, a strong armory with mighty shields
questions.explanation: Verse 4:4 likens the neck to 'the tower of David builded for an armoury,' symbolizing integrity, protection, and strength, encouraging believers to cultivate moral fortitude.

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 4 highlights the importance of generous love and stewardship within marriage by describing the beloved’s qualities as precious and valuable.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses such as 4:11 and 4:13-14 describe the beloved with rich imagery of spices and honey, illustrating the preciousness and value of love, which encourages generous and faithful stewardship in marriage.

questions.question: How does the imagery in Song of Solomon 4:14 teach us about the importance of spiritual discipline in Christian life?
options: By listing spices like myrrh and aloes, symbolizing the richness that comes from discipline
By rejecting any form of self-control
By focusing only on external appearances
questions.correctAnswer: By listing spices like myrrh and aloes, symbolizing the richness that comes from discipline
questions.explanation: Verse 4:14 names various spices, symbolizing the variety and richness gained through spiritual discipline, encouraging believers to cultivate their inner spiritual life.

questions.question: A believer wants to be an effective witness in their family. What lesson about affectionate communication can be taken from Song of Solomon 4:3?
options: Speak with comely and loving speech, like lips of scarlet
Speak harshly and critically to show authority
Use only formal and distant words
questions.correctAnswer: Speak with comely and loving speech, like lips of scarlet
questions.explanation: Verse 4:3 says, 'Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet, and thy speech is comely,' highlighting the power of gracious and loving communication in relationships and witness.

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 4 encourages believers to seek fellowship and mutual support by inviting their spouse to come from Lebanon and enjoy the mountains together.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 4:8 invites 'Come with me from Lebanon,' emphasizing companionship and mutual encouragement, which applies to Christian fellowship and support.

questions.question: How can Song of Solomon 4:10 encourage believers to have gratitude for the love they receive in marriage?
options: By comparing love to wine and spices, highlighting its sweetness and richness
By minimizing the value of love
By suggesting love is easy to obtain
By focusing on material wealth instead of love
questions.correctAnswer: By comparing love to wine and spices, highlighting its sweetness and richness
questions.explanation: Verse 4:10 says, 'How much better is thy love than wine! and the smell of thine ointments than all spices!' encouraging appreciation and gratitude for love’s blessings.

questions.question: How does the metaphor of the garden and fountain in Song of Solomon 4:15 teach about spiritual nourishment and growth?
options: A fountain of gardens and living waters symbolizes ongoing spiritual life and nourishment
Gardens and fountains represent worldly pleasures only
Spiritual growth is unnecessary once faith begins
Fountains imply dryness and lack of vitality
questions.correctAnswer: A fountain of gardens and living waters symbolizes ongoing spiritual life and nourishment
questions.explanation: Verse 4:15 calls the beloved 'A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters,' teaching believers about the importance of continual spiritual nourishment and vitality.

questions.question: A believer wants to foster forgiveness and reconciliation in their marriage. What insight from Song of Solomon 4:9 would you share?
options: Love can captivate the heart powerfully, encouraging forgiveness and unity
Love should be conditional on perfect behavior
Reconciliation is unnecessary if hurt occurs
questions.correctAnswer: Love can captivate the heart powerfully, encouraging forgiveness and unity
questions.explanation: Verse 4:9 says, 'Thou hast ravished my heart,' illustrating how powerful love fosters willingness to forgive and reconcile.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 4:2 encourage believers to have honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: By describing teeth as a flock of sheep, all healthy and not barren, symbolizing completeness and honesty
By promoting deceit as a way to succeed
questions.correctAnswer: By describing teeth as a flock of sheep, all healthy and not barren, symbolizing completeness and honesty
questions.explanation: Verse 4:2 describes teeth as 'a flock of sheep... whereof every one bear twins, and none is barren,' symbolizing wholeness and integrity, encouraging honesty in life.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Song of Solomon 4:5 compares the beloved's two breasts to two young ______ that feed among the lilies.
questions.correctAnswer: roes
questions.explanation: Verse 4:5 states, 'Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins, which feed among the lilies,' using gentle animal imagery to describe purity and tenderness.

hard.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Song of Solomon Chapter 4.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:1, the beloved's hair is compared to what imagery from the region of Mount Gilead?
questions.correctAnswer: A flock of goats
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:1 compares the beloved's hair to 'a flock of goats, that appear from mount Gilead,' highlighting pastoral imagery typical of the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What does the comparison of the beloved’s teeth to 'a flock of sheep that are even shorn' in Song of Solomon 4:2 symbolize?
questions.correctAnswer: Purity and abundance
questions.explanation: The teeth are likened to well-cared-for sheep, symbolizing purity and fertility, as each 'bear twins, and none is barren' (Song of Solomon 4:2), reflecting cultural values of fruitfulness.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in the description of the beloved's features throughout Song of Solomon 4?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The chapter extensively uses similes, such as comparing lips to 'a thread of scarlet' and temples to 'a piece of a pomegranate' (Song of Solomon 4:3), to convey beauty.

questions.question: Song of Solomon 4:4 likens the beloved’s neck to the 'tower of David builded for an armoury.' What is the significance of this metaphor in its historical context?
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes strength and protection
questions.explanation: The tower of David was a well-known fortified structure in Jerusalem, symbolizing defense and might. Comparing the neck to this tower (Song of Solomon 4:4) reflects strength and dignity.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'my sister, my spouse' used repeatedly in this chapter (e.g., Song of Solomon 4:9 and 4:10) in its cultural and literary context?
options: It denotes intimacy and familial closeness
It is a legal term for marriage
It is a title of religious office
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes intimacy and familial closeness
questions.explanation: The phrase reflects an ancient Hebrew poetic device expressing deep affection and intimacy, blending family and marital bonds (Song of Solomon 4:9, 4:10).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:6, the beloved speaks of going 'to the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.' How does this imagery foreshadow New Testament themes?
options: It prefigures the gifts of the Magi to Jesus
It symbolizes the exile to Babylon
It represents the coming of the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the gifts of the Magi to Jesus
questions.explanation: Myrrh and frankincense are gifts brought by the Magi in Matthew 2:11, and here symbolize preciousness and sacredness, foreshadowing Christ’s birth and mission.

questions.question: Which Hebrew poetic structure is evidenced in the parallelism between the phrases 'a garden inclosed' and 'a spring shut up, a fountain sealed' in Song of Solomon 4:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Synonymous parallelism
questions.explanation: The phrases repeat similar ideas using different imagery to emphasize purity and exclusivity, characteristic of synonymous parallelism (Song of Solomon 4:12).

questions.question: How does the imagery of spices and aromatic plants in Song of Solomon 4:13-14 reflect the ancient Near Eastern cultural context?
options: They signify wealth, fertility, and sacredness
questions.correctAnswer: They signify wealth, fertility, and sacredness
questions.explanation: Spices like spikenard, saffron, and frankincense were valuable commodities used in worship and celebrations, symbolizing prosperity and holiness (Song of Solomon 4:13-14).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the phrase 'there is no spot in thee' in Song of Solomon 4:7 when considering typology in Christian interpretation?
options: It prefigures the doctrine of the Immaculate Conception
It refers to a ritual cleansing
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the doctrine of the Immaculate Conception
questions.explanation: The phrase 'there is no spot in thee' is interpreted typologically as a foreshadowing of Mary’s sinlessness, an important Christian doctrine (Song of Solomon 4:7).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:8, the beloved calls from Lebanon and mentions 'lions' dens' and 'mountains of the leopards.' What does this geographical and zoological imagery imply in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: A call to courage and overcoming dangers
questions.correctAnswer: A call to courage and overcoming dangers
questions.explanation: Lions and leopards were symbols of danger and power; invoking these mountains suggests a bold summons to face challenges (Song of Solomon 4:8).

questions.question: True or False: In Song of Solomon 4:11, the beloved's lips are compared to honeycomb, emphasizing sweetness and delight.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The lips are described as dropping 'as the honeycomb,' which symbolizes sweetness and pleasure, a common poetic image (Song of Solomon 4:11).

questions.question: Which of the following best encapsulates the overarching theme developed in Song of Solomon 4 as it relates to broader biblical themes?
options: The intimate love between God and His people
The prophecy of the coming Messiah
The establishment of the Davidic kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The intimate love between God and His people
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4 employs intimate and affectionate imagery to portray the love relationship, often interpreted allegorically as reflecting God's love for Israel or Christ's love for the Church.

questions.question: What is the function of the repeated exhortation to 'Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south' in Song of Solomon 4:16?
options: To invoke natural forces to facilitate love and fruitfulness
To call for a harvest festival
questions.correctAnswer: To invoke natural forces to facilitate love and fruitfulness
questions.explanation: The north and south winds symbolize natural elements that stir the garden, metaphorically representing the awakening of love and fertility (Song of Solomon 4:16).

questions.question: The mention of 'a fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon' in Song of Solomon 4:15 primarily symbolizes what concept in ancient Semitic literature?
questions.correctAnswer: Abundance and life-giving sustenance
questions.explanation: Water imagery in ancient Near Eastern texts often symbolizes life and blessing, and here the fountain and streams emphasize the beloved's vitality and richness (Song of Solomon 4:15).

questions.question: What is the significance of the use of twin imagery in Song of Solomon 4:2 and 4:5?
options: It emphasizes completeness and perfect harmony
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes completeness and perfect harmony
questions.explanation: The twins imagery in teeth and breasts underscores a theme of balance and perfection in the beloved’s beauty and nature (Song of Solomon 4:2, 4:5).

theological.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Song of Solomon Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:1, what imagery is used to describe the beloved's eyes?
questions.correctAnswer: Doves' eyes within thy locks
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:1 describes the beloved's eyes as 'doves' eyes within thy locks,' symbolizing purity and gentleness, consistent with biblical imagery such as in Genesis 8:11 where doves represent peace, and Psalm 68:13 associating doves with beauty and innocence.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 4:4, the beloved's neck is compared to which of the following?
options: The tower of David builded for an armoury
The bronze serpent lifted in the wilderness
The pillar of cloud by day
questions.correctAnswer: The tower of David builded for an armoury
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:4 compares the beloved’s neck to 'the tower of David builded for an armoury,' symbolizing strength and protection, echoing Old Testament images of God as a fortress (Psalm 18:2) and Christ as the strong tower (Proverbs 18:10).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'my sister, my spouse' in Song of Solomon 4:9 imply about the nature of the relationship?
questions.correctAnswer: A deep, covenantal intimacy
questions.explanation: The phrase 'my sister, my spouse' in Song of Solomon 4:9 reflects a profound covenantal intimacy, combining familial closeness with marital union, consistent with biblical covenant language (Malachi 2:14) and the church as the Bride of Christ (Ephesians 5:25-32).

questions.question: Song of Solomon 4:6 mentions 'the mountain of myrrh' and 'the hill of frankincense.' What theological symbolism can be drawn from these spices?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificial offerings and worship
questions.explanation: Myrrh and frankincense were used in Old Testament worship and sacrifices (Exodus 30:34-38; Psalm 45:8), symbolizing the beloved’s preciousness and the sanctity of the relationship, pointing to Christ’s sacrificial role and priestly intercession (Hebrews 7:26-27).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:12, the beloved is described as 'a garden inclosed.' What does this metaphor signify theologically?
options: Purity and sanctity of the covenant bride
questions.correctAnswer: Purity and sanctity of the covenant bride
questions.explanation: The metaphor 'a garden inclosed' in Song of Solomon 4:12 conveys purity, sanctity, and exclusivity of the covenant relationship, paralleling Old Testament imagery of Israel as God's enclosed garden (Ezekiel 28:13) and the church as the pure bride of Christ (Revelation 19:7-8).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 4:7 express the beloved's perfection?
options: Thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:7 declares the beloved 'all fair' and without blemish, symbolizing the ideal of purity and holiness, resonating with biblical themes of Christ’s sinlessness (Hebrews 4:15) and the church being presented blameless before God (Ephesians 5:27).

questions.question: Song of Solomon 4:10 compares love to which of the following?
questions.correctAnswer: Better than wine
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:10 states, 'how much better is thy love than wine,' highlighting the intoxicating and joyous nature of love, paralleling biblical imagery where wine often symbolizes joy and blessing (Psalm 104:15; John 2:1-11).

questions.question: What does the description of the beloved's teeth as 'a flock of sheep that are even shorn' in Song of Solomon 4:2 symbolize?
questions.correctAnswer: Purity and completeness
questions.explanation: The imagery of evenly shorn sheep in Song of Solomon 4:2 symbolizes purity, completeness, and health, consistent with the biblical metaphor of the flock representing God's people (Psalm 23:1) and the perfection expected in the covenant community (1 Peter 1:16).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:11, what two substances are said to be under the beloved's tongue?
questions.correctAnswer: Honey and milk
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:11 mentions 'honey and milk are under thy tongue,' signifying sweetness and nourishment, echoing the Promised Land described as 'a land flowing with milk and honey' (Exodus 3:8), symbolizing God's provision and blessing.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'a fountain of gardens, a well of living waters' in Song of Solomon 4:15 most closely represent?
questions.correctAnswer: Abundant life and spiritual refreshment
questions.explanation: The phrase in Song of Solomon 4:15 symbolizes abundant life and spiritual refreshment, consistent with biblical themes where 'living waters' represent the Holy Spirit and eternal life (John 4:14; Revelation 22:1), indicating the vitality of the beloved’s presence.

questions.question: Song of Solomon 4:8 invites the beloved to come from Lebanon and other places. Theologically, what does this invitation reflect?
options: The call to covenant fellowship and intimacy
questions.correctAnswer: The call to covenant fellowship and intimacy
questions.explanation: The invitation in Song of Solomon 4:8 reflects a call to covenant fellowship and intimate union, symbolizing God's call to His people to enter into a loving relationship (Isaiah 54:5; Hosea 2:16), and Christ's invitation to the church (Revelation 3:20).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'two young roes that are twins' feeding among the lilies in Song of Solomon 4:5?
options: Delicate beauty and harmony in love
questions.correctAnswer: Delicate beauty and harmony in love
questions.explanation: The imagery of 'two young roes that are twins' feeding among lilies in Song of Solomon 4:5 conveys delicate beauty and harmony, symbolizing the mutual affection and unity in the marital relationship, akin to the harmony and peace depicted in Isaiah 11:6-9.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:13-14, a variety of spices and plants are mentioned. What doctrinal theme do these images most likely emphasize?
options: The richness and diversity of God's blessings
questions.correctAnswer: The richness and diversity of God's blessings
questions.explanation: The listing of spices and plants in Song of Solomon 4:13-14 emphasizes the richness and diversity of God's blessings, reflecting the abundance and beauty of creation (Psalm 104:14-15) and the manifold grace of God (1 Peter 4:10).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 4:16, the north and south winds are called to blow upon the garden. What eschatological or spiritual meaning can be drawn from this?
options: The Spirit's revitalizing power over the church
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit's revitalizing power over the church
questions.explanation: The winds in Song of Solomon 4:16 symbolize the Spirit's revitalizing and life-giving power over the church, akin to the breath of God that brings life (Ezekiel 37:9-10) and the Holy Spirit's work in renewing believers (John 3:8).

questions.question: How does the description in Song of Solomon 4:3 of the beloved's lips and speech contribute to a Christological understanding?
options: Lips like a thread of scarlet, speech comely, symbolizing the beauty and power of Christ's word
Lips of fire, speech harsh, symbolizing judgment
Lips like stone, speech cold, symbolizing law
questions.correctAnswer: Lips like a thread of scarlet, speech comely, symbolizing the beauty and power of Christ's word
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 4:3 describes lips like a thread of scarlet and comely speech, representing the beauty, grace, and power of Christ’s word (John 1:14; Hebrews 4:12), highlighting His role as the divine Logos and lover of the church.
